maml:description.maml:para: Adds a DNS record to a record set.

The Add-AzureRmDnsRecordConfig cmdlet adds a Domain Name System (DNS) record to a RecordSet object. The RecordSet object is an offline object, and changes to it do not change the DNS responses until after you run the Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet to persist the change to the Microsoft Azure DNS service.
You cannot remove SOA records.
You can pass the RecordSet object to this cmdlet as a parameter or by using the pipeline operator.
Specifies the domain name for a canonical name (CNAME) record.
Specifies the RecordSet object to edit.
Specifies the mail exchange server name for a mail exchange (MX) record.
Specifies the preference for an MX record.
Specifies the RecordSet object to edit.
Specifies an IPv4 address for an A record.
Specifies the RecordSet object to edit.
Specifies an IPv6 address for an AAAA record.
Specifies the RecordSet object to edit.
Specifies the name server for a name server (NS) record.
Specifies the RecordSet object to edit.
Specifies the port for a service (SRV) record.
Specifies the priority for an SRV record.
Specifies the RecordSet object to edit.
Specifies the target for an SRV record.
Specifies the weight for an SRV record.
Specifies the DNAME of a pointer resource (PTR) record.
Specifies the RecordSet object to edit.
Specifies the RecordSet object to edit.
Specifies the value for a TXT record.
Specifies the domain name for a canonical name (CNAME) record.
Specifies the mail exchange server name for a mail exchange (MX) record.
Specifies an IPv4 address for an A record.
Specifies an IPv6 address for an AAAA record.
Specifies the name server for a name server (NS) record.
Specifies the port for a service (SRV) record.
Specifies the preference for an MX record.
Specifies the priority for an SRV record.
Specifies the DNAME of a pointer resource (PTR) record.
Specifies the RecordSet object to edit.
Specifies the target for an SRV record.
Specifies the value for a TXT record.
Specifies the weight for an SRV record.

You can pipe a RecordSet object to this cmdlet. This is an offline representation of the RecordSet, and changes to it do not change DNS responses until after you run the Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns the modified RecordSet object. In addition, the object passed in is modified directly.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Add an A record to a record set

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds an IPv4 address as an A record to the record set stored in the $RecordSet variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Add an AAAA record to a record set

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds an IPv6 address as an AAAA record to the record set stored in the $RecordSet variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Add a CNAME record to a record set

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds contoso.com as a CNAME record to the record set stored in the $RecordSet variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Add an MX record to a record set

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the specified mail exchange server as an MX record to the record set stored in the $RecordSet variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: Add an NS record to a record set

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a name server as an NS record to the record set stored in the $RecordSet variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 6: Add an SRV record to a record set

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the specified service locator as an SRV record to the record set stored in the $RecordSet variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 7: Add a TXT record to a record set
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureRmDnsRecordConfig -RecordSet $RecordSet -Value "This is a TXT Record"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a TXT record to the record set stored in the $RecordSet variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new Dns Record that can be added to a record set.
The New-AzureRmDnsRecordConfig cmdlet creates a Domain Name System (DNS) record object that can be used to create record sets.
Specifies the domain name for a canonical name (CNAME) record.
Specifies the mail exchange server name for a mail exchange (MX) record.
Specifies the preference for an MX record.
Specifies an IPv4 address for an A record.
Specifies an IPv6 address for an AAAA record.
Specifies the name server for a name server (NS) record.
Specifies the port for a service (SRV) record.
Specifies the priority for an SRV record.
Specifies the target for an SRV record.
Specifies the weight for an SRV record.
Specifies the DNAME of a pointer resource (PTR) record.
Specifies the value for a TXT record.
Specifies the domain name for a canonical name (CNAME) record.
Specifies the mail exchange server name for a mail exchange (MX) record.
Specifies an IPv4 address for an A record.
Specifies an IPv6 address for an AAAA record.
Specifies the name server for a name server (NS) record.
Specifies the port for a service (SRV) record.
Specifies the preference for an MX record.
Specifies the priority for an SRV record.
Specifies the DNAME of a pointer resource (PTR) record.
Specifies the target for an SRV record.
Specifies the value for a TXT record.
Specifies the weight for an SRV record.
This cmdlet returns the a Record object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Create a record set with a single A record --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new RecordSet named www as type A in the zone named myzone.com with a TTL of 3600 seconds. The record set has a single A record

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Create a record set with multiple AAAA records --------------------------
Example 3: Create a CNAME record to add to a record set

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a record with contoso.com as a CNAME record.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Create a MX record to add to a record set

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the specified mail exchange server as an MX record.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: Create NS record to add to a record set

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a NS record.

command:example.maml:title: Example 6: Create SRV record

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates the specified service locator as an SRV record.

command:example.maml:title: Example 7: Add a TXT record
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureRmDnsRecordConfig -Value "This is a TXT Record"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a TXT record that can be added to a record set.
Creates a record set with a PTR record

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a DNS record set.
The Get-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet gets the Domain Name System (DNS) record set with the specified name and type, in the specified zone.

If you do not specify the Name or RecordType parameters, this cmdlet returns all record sets of the specified type in the zone. If you specify the RecordType parameter but not the Name parameter, this cmdlet returns all record sets of the specified record type.

You can use the pipeline operator to pass a DnsZone object to this cmdlet, or you can pass a DnsZone object as the Zone parameter, or alternatively you can specify the zone and resource group by name.
Specifies a suffix to use as a filter when you get multiple record sets.
Specifies the name of the RecordSet to get. If you do not specify the Name parameter, all record sets of the specified type are returned.
Specifies the type of DNS record that this cmdlet gets.

Valid values are:
-- A -- AAAA -- CNAME -- MX -- NS -- PTR -- SOA -- SRV -- TXT
If you do not specify the RecordType parameter, this cmdlet returns record sets of all types.
Specifies the DNS zone that contains the record set that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies a suffix to use as a filter when you get multiple record sets.
Specifies the name of the RecordSet to get. If you do not specify the Name parameter, all record sets of the specified type are returned.
Specifies the type of DNS record that this cmdlet gets.

Valid values are:
-- A -- AAAA -- CNAME -- MX -- NS -- PTR -- SOA -- SRV -- TXT
If you do not specify the RecordType parameter, this cmdlet returns record sets of all types.
Specifies the resource group that contains the DNS zone.
Specifies the name of the DNS zone that contains the record set to get.
Specifies a suffix to use as a filter when you get multiple record sets.
Specifies the name of the RecordSet to get. If you do not specify the Name parameter, all record sets of the specified type are returned.
Specifies the type of DNS record that this cmdlet gets.

Valid values are:
-- A -- AAAA -- CNAME -- MX -- NS -- PTR -- SOA -- SRV -- TXT
If you do not specify the RecordType parameter, this cmdlet returns record sets of all types.
Specifies the resource group that contains the DNS zone.
Specifies the DNS zone that contains the record set that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies the name of the DNS zone that contains the record set to get.
You can pipe a DnsZone object to this cmdlet. The DnsZone object represents the zone in which to look for the RecordSet object.

This cmdlet returns one or more objects that represents the record sets that are found. There will be at most one RecordSet returned if the Name and RecordType parameters are specified, otherwise multiple RecordSet objects are returned as an array.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get record sets with a specified name and type

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the record set of record type A named www in the specified resource group and zone, and then stores it in the $RecordSet variable. Because the Name and RecordType parameters are specified, only one RecordSet object is returned.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get record sets of a specified type

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets an array of all record sets of record type A in the zone named myzone.com in the resource group named MyResourceGroup, and then stores them in the $RecordSets variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get all record sets in a zone

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets an array of all record sets in the zone named myzone.com in the resource group named MyResourceGroup, and then stores them in the $RecordSets variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a DNS zone.

The Get-AzureRmDnsZone cmdlet gets a Domain Name System (DNS) zone from the specified resource group. If you specify the Name parameter, a single DnsZone object is returned. If you do not specify the Name parameter, an array containing all of the zones in the specified resource group is returned. You can use the DnsZone object to update the zone, for example you can add RecordSet objects to it.
Specifies a suffix to use as a filter when you get multiple zones.
Specifies the name of the DNS zone to get. If you do not specify the Name parameter, all zones in the specified resource group are returned.
Specifies the resource group that contains the zone to get.
Specifies a suffix to use as a filter when you get multiple zones.
Specifies the name of the DNS zone to get. If you do not specify the Name parameter, all zones in the specified resource group are returned.
Specifies the resource group that contains the zone to get.
This cmdlet does not allow you to pipe input.
This cmdlet returns an object that represents the DNS zone. If the zone name is not specified, an array of zone objects is returned.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get a zone

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the zone named myzone.com from the specified resource group, and then stores it in the $Zone variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get all of the zones in a resource group

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all of the zones in the specified resource group, and then stores it in the $Zones variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a DNS record set.

The New-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet creates a new Domain Name System (DNS) record set with the specified name and type in the specified zone. A RecordSet object is a set of DNS records with the same name and type. Note that the name is relative to the zone and not the fully qualified name.
The record set will not contain any DNS records. Use Add-AzureRmDnsRecordConfig and Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSetto add records to the record set and commit changes.
You can use the pipeline operator to pass a DnsZone object to this cmdlet, or you can pass a DnsZone object as the Zone parameter, or alternatively you can specify the zone by name.
If a matching RecordSet already exists (same name and record type), you must specify the Overwrite parameter, otherwise the cmdlet will not create a new RecordSet.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Indicates that this cmdlet overwrites the specified RecordSet if it exists. You will be prompted to confirm the operation unless you specify the Force parameter.

Specifies an array of tags to associate with the RecordSet. Metadata are name-value pairs that are represented as hash tables, for example @(@{"Name"="dept"; "Value"="shopping"}, @{"Name"="env"; "Value"="production"}).
Specifies the name of the RecordSet to create.
Specifies the type of DNS record to create.

Valid values are:
-- A -- AAAA -- CNAME -- MX -- NS -- PTR -- SRV -- TXT
SOA records are created automatically when the zone is created and cannot be created manually.
Specifies the resource group that contains the zone.
Specifies the Time to Live (TTL) for the DNS RecordSet.
Specifies the name of the zone in which to create the RecordSet.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Indicates that this cmdlet overwrites the specified RecordSet if it exists. You will be prompted to confirm the operation unless you specify the Force parameter.

Specifies an array of tags to associate with the RecordSet. Metadata are name-value pairs that are represented as hash tables, for example @(@{"Name"="dept"; "Value"="shopping"}, @{"Name"="env"; "Value"="production"}).
Specifies the name of the RecordSet to create.
Specifies the type of DNS record to create.

Valid values are:
-- A -- AAAA -- CNAME -- MX -- NS -- PTR -- SRV -- TXT
SOA records are created automatically when the zone is created and cannot be created manually.
Specifies the Time to Live (TTL) for the DNS RecordSet.
Specifies the DnsZone in which to create the RecordSet.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the name of the RecordSet to create.
Indicates that this cmdlet overwrites the specified RecordSet if it exists. You will be prompted to confirm the operation unless you specify the Force parameter.
Specifies the type of DNS record to create.

Valid values are:
-- A -- AAAA -- CNAME -- MX -- NS -- PTR -- SRV -- TXT
SOA records are created automatically when the zone is created and cannot be created manually.
Specifies the resource group that contains the zone.

Specifies an array of tags to associate with the RecordSet. Metadata are name-value pairs that are represented as hash tables, for example @(@{"Name"="dept"; "Value"="shopping"}, @{"Name"="env"; "Value"="production"}).
Specifies the Time to Live (TTL) for the DNS RecordSet.
Specifies the DnsZone in which to create the RecordSet.
Specifies the name of the zone in which to create the RecordSet.
You can pipe a DnsZone object to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns a RecordSet object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Create a record set with a single A record --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new RecordSet named www as type A in the zone named myzone.com with a TTL of 3600 seconds. The record set has a single A record

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Create a record set with multiple AAAA records --------------------------
-------------------------- Example 3 : Create an empty record set (without records) --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new RecordSet named www as type A in the zone named myzone.com with a TTL of 3600 seconds.
Note that the record set will not contain any DNS records. Use Add-AzureRmDnsRecordConfig and Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet to add records to the record set and commit changes.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new DNS zone.

The New-AzureRmDnsZone cmdlet creates a new Domain Name System (DNS) zone in the specified resource group. You must specify a unique name for the Name parameter or the cmdlet will return an error. After the zone is created, use the New-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet to create record sets in the zone.

Specifies an array of tags to associate with the DNS zone. Metadata are name-value pairs represented as hash tables, for example, @(@{"Name"="dept"; "Value"="shopping"}, @{"Name"="env"; "Value"="production"})
Specifies the name of the DNS zone to create.
Specifies the resource group in which to create the zone.
Specifies the name of the DNS zone to create.
Specifies the resource group in which to create the zone.

Specifies an array of tags to associate with the DNS zone. Metadata are name-value pairs represented as hash tables, for example, @(@{"Name"="dept"; "Value"="shopping"}, @{"Name"="env"; "Value"="production"})
You cannot pipe input to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns an object that represents the new DNS zone.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a DNS zone

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new DNS zone named myzone.com in the specified resource group, and then stores it in the $Zone variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a DNS record from a record set.

The Remove-AzureRmDnsRecordConfig cmdlet removes a Domain Name System (DNS) record from a record set. The RecordSet object is an offline object, and changes to it do not change the DNS responses until after you run the Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet to persist the change to the Microsoft Azure DNS service.
To remove a record, all the fields for that record type must match exactly. You cannot add or remove SOA records.
You can pass the RecordSet object to this cmdlet as a parameter or by using the pipeline operator.
Specifies the domain name for a canonical name (CNAME) record.
Specifies the RecordSet object that contains the record to remove.
Specifies the mail exchange server name for a mail exchange (MX) record.
Specifies the preference for an MX record.
Specifies the RecordSet object that contains the record to remove.
Specifies an IPv4 address for an A record.
Specifies the RecordSet object that contains the record to remove.
Specifies an IPv6 address for an AAAA record.
Specifies the RecordSet object that contains the record to remove.
Specifies the name server for a name server (NS) record.
Specifies the RecordSet object that contains the record to remove.
Specifies the port for a service (SRV) record.
Specifies the priority for an SRV record.
Specifies the RecordSet object that contains the record to remove.
Specifies the target for an SRV record.
Specifies the weight for an SRV record.
Specifies the DNAME of a pointer (PTR) record.
Specifies the RecordSet object that contains the record to remove.
Specifies the RecordSet object that contains the record to remove.
Specifies the value for a TXT record.
Specifies the domain name for a canonical name (CNAME) record.
Specifies the mail exchange server name for a mail exchange (MX) record.
Specifies an IPv4 address for an A record.
Specifies an IPv6 address for an AAAA record.
Specifies the name server for a name server (NS) record.
Specifies the port for a service (SRV) record.
Specifies the preference for an MX record.
Specifies the priority for an SRV record.
Specifies the DNAME of a pointer (PTR) record.
Specifies the RecordSet object that contains the record to remove.
Specifies the target for an SRV record.
Specifies the value for a TXT record.
Specifies the weight for an SRV record.
You can pipe a DnsRecordSet object to this cmdlet. This is an offline representation of the record set and updates to it do not change DNS responses until after you run Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet.
This cmdlet returns the modified RecordSet object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove a specified A record

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the A record with the specified IP address from the record set stored in $RecordSet.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Remove a specified SRV record

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the SRV record from the $RecordSet variable where Port=8080, Priority=0, Weight=5, and Target=target.example.com.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a record set.
The Remove-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet deletes the specified record set from the specified zone. You cannot delete SOA or name server (NS) records that are automatically created at the zone apex.

You can pass a RecordSet object to this cmdlet by using the pipeline operator or as a parameter. To identify a record set by name and type without using a RecordSet object, you must pass the zone as a DnsZone object to this cmdlet by using the pipeline operator or as a parameter, or alternatively you can specify the ZoneName and ResourceGroupName parameters.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the name of the RecordSet to remove.
Specifies the type of DNS record.

Valid values are:
-- A -- AAAA -- CNAME -- MX -- NS -- PTR -- SRV -- TXT
You cannot remove SOA record sets.
Specifies the DNS zone that contains the RecordSet to delete.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the name of the RecordSet to remove.
Specifies the type of DNS record.

Valid values are:
-- A -- AAAA -- CNAME -- MX -- NS -- PTR -- SRV -- TXT
You cannot remove SOA record sets.
Specifies the resource group that contains the DNS zone that contains the RecordSet to delete.
Specifies the name of the zone that contains the RecordSet to delete.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Indicates that this cmdlet ignores the entity tag (Etag) when the record set is deleted, and that the record set is deleted even if it has changed since the last retrieval.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the RecordSet object to remove.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the name of the RecordSet to remove.
Indicates that this cmdlet ignores the entity tag (Etag) when the record set is deleted, and that the record set is deleted even if it has changed since the last retrieval.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the RecordSet object to remove.
Specifies the type of DNS record.

Valid values are:
-- A -- AAAA -- CNAME -- MX -- NS -- PTR -- SRV -- TXT
You cannot remove SOA record sets.
Specifies the resource group that contains the DNS zone that contains the RecordSet to delete.
Specifies the DNS zone that contains the RecordSet to delete.
Specifies the name of the zone that contains the RecordSet to delete.
You can pipe a RecordSet object to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet does not generate any output.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove a record set
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$RecordSet = Get-AzureRmDnsRecordSet -Name "www" -ResourceGroupName "MyResourceGroup" -ZoneName "myzone.com" PS C:\> Remove-AzureRmDnsRecordSet -RecordSet $RecordSet

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the specified record set, and then stores it in the $RecordSet variable.The second command removes the record set in $RecordSet.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a DNS zone from a resource group.

The Remove-AzureRmDnsZone cmdlet removes a Domain Name System (DNS) zone from a specified resource group. Before you run this cmdlet, you must first remove all record sets from the zone, except for the automatically-created SOA and NS record sets at the zone apex.
You can pass a DnsZone object as a parameter or by using the pipeline operator, or alternatively you can specify the ZoneName and ResourceGroupName parameters.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the name of the DNS zone that this cmdlet removes.
Specifies the name of the resource group that contains the zone to remove.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Indicates that this cmdlet ignores the entity tag (Etag) when it deletes the resource group, and that the resource group is removed even if it has changed since the last retrieval.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the DNS zone to remove.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the name of the DNS zone that this cmdlet removes.
Indicates that this cmdlet ignores the entity tag (Etag) when it deletes the resource group, and that the resource group is removed even if it has changed since the last retrieval.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the name of the resource group that contains the zone to remove.
Specifies the DNS zone to remove.
You can pipe a DnsZone object to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet does not generate any output.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove a zone

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the zone named myzone.com from the resource group named MyResourceGroup.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a DNS record set.

The Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet updates a record set in the Azure DNS service from an offline RecordSet object. If the entity tag (Etag) has changed since the last retrieval, the call will fail unless the Overwrite parameter switch is specified.
You can pass a RecordSet object as a parameter or by using the pipeline operator.
Indicates that this cmdlet ignores the Etag when deleting the record set, and that the record set is deleted even if it has changed since the last retrieval.
Specifies the RecordSet to update.
Indicates that this cmdlet ignores the Etag when deleting the record set, and that the record set is deleted even if it has changed since the last retrieval.
Specifies the RecordSet to update.
You can pass a RecordSet object to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns an object that represents the updated RecordSet object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Update a record set
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$RecordSet = Get-AzureRmDnsRecordSet -ResourceGroupName "MyResourceGroup" -ZoneName "myzone.com" -Name "www" -RecordType A PS C:\> Add-AzureRmDnsRecordConfig –RecordSet $RecordSet -Ipv4Address "172.16.0.0" PS C:\> Add-AzureRmDnsRecordConfig –RecordSet $RecordSet -Ipv4Address "172.31.255.255" PS C:\> $RecordSet | Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command uses the Get-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet to get the specified record set, and then stores it in the $RecordSet variable. The second and third commands are off-line operations to add two A records to the newly created record set. The final command uses the pipeline operator to pass $RecordSet to the Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet to propagate the update.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Update an SOA record
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$RecordSet = Get-AzureRmDnsRecordSet -Name "@" -RecordType SOA -Zone $ZonePS PS C:\> $RecordSet.Records[0].Email = "pfuller.test.com" PS C:\> Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet -RecordSet $RecordSet

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command uses the Get-AzureRmDnsRecordset cmdlet to get the specified record set, and then stores it in the $RecordSet variable.The second command updates the specified SOA record in $RecordSet.The final command uses the Set-AzureRmDnsRecordSet cmdlet to propagate the update in $RecordSet.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a DNS zone.
The Set-AzureRmDnsZone cmdlet updates the specified DnsZone. This cmdlet does not update the RecordSet objects in the zone.
You can pass a DnsZone object as a parameter or by using the pipeline operator, or alternatively you can specify the ZoneName and ResourceGroupName parameters

Specifies an array of tags to associate with the DNS zone. Metadata are name-value pairs that are represented as hashtables, for instance, @(@{"Name"="dept"; "Value"="shopping"}, @{"Name"="env"; "Value"="production"})
Specifies the name of the DNS zone to update.
Specifies the name of the resource group that contains the zone to update.
Indicates that this cmdlet ignores the entity tag (Etag) when it deletes the record set, and that the record set is deleted even if it has changed since the last retrieval.
Specifies the DNS zone to update.
Specifies the name of the DNS zone to update.
Indicates that this cmdlet ignores the entity tag (Etag) when it deletes the record set, and that the record set is deleted even if it has changed since the last retrieval.
Specifies the name of the resource group that contains the zone to update.

Specifies an array of tags to associate with the DNS zone. Metadata are name-value pairs that are represented as hashtables, for instance, @(@{"Name"="dept"; "Value"="shopping"}, @{"Name"="env"; "Value"="production"})
Specifies the DNS zone to update.
You can pipe a DnsZone object to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns a DnsZone object that represents the updated DNS zone with a new Etag.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Update a DNS zone
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Zone = Get-AzureRmDnsZone -Name "myzone.com" -ResourceGroupName "MyResourceGroup" PS C:\> $Zone.Metadata = @(@{"Name"="Dept"; "Value"="Electrical"}) PS C:\> $Zone | Set-AzureRmDnsZone

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the zone named myzone.com from the specified resource group, and then stores it in the $Zone variable. The second command updates the tags for $Zone.The final command passes $Zone to the Set-AzureRmDnsZone cmdlet by the pipeline operator.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Update tags for a zone

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command updates the tags for the zone named myzone.com without first explicitly getting the zone.
